articles.headline: Market Turbulence Serves as Reminder to Tread Lightly
articles.snippet: Experts caution against overreacting to recent tremors in the markets. Investors may assess their portfolios and realize the mix is just right.
articles.abstract: Experts caution against overreacting to recent tremors in the markets. Investors may assess their portfolios and realize the mix is just right.
articles.lead_paragraph: The recent tremors in the stock and bond markets are unnerving — and may leave average investors feeling as if they should be doing something to protect themselves.

articles.headline: Analysts Ask What’s Next for Google
articles.snippet: Even though Google has expanded beyond its core search business, nothing has been as profitable as search, its original golden goose.
articles.abstract: Even though Google has expanded beyond its core search business, nothing has been as profitable as search, its original golden goose.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google is still pulling in money hand over fist, but Wall Street is hungry for the company’s next act.

articles.headline: Shivers in the Markets Portend a Freeze in Deal Circles
articles.snippet: Volatility tends to send deal makers to the sidelines until they get a better sense of prices, while companies planning an initial stock offering also shy away.
articles.abstract: Volatility tends to send deal makers to the sidelines until they get a better sense of prices, while companies planning an initial stock offering also shy away.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s big year of deal-making may have ended early — after peaking on the morning of Sept. 19.

articles.headline: Fears That Pimco and Other Big Firms Could Be Unable to Unload Risky Bonds
articles.snippet: Financial experts warn that a small group of giant asset managers that have amassed high-risk, high-yield bonds could find themselves unable to raise enough cash during a sell-off.
articles.abstract: Financial experts warn that a small group of giant asset managers that have amassed high-risk, high-yield bonds could find themselves unable to raise enough cash during a sell-off.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to high-risk bonds, the asset management giant Pimco has pretty much cornered the global market.

articles.headline: What a 401(k) Plan Really Owes Employees
articles.snippet: A case taken up by the Supreme Court concerns whether trustees for a corporate 401(k) are liable years after choosing a class of mutual fund with higher fees.
articles.abstract: A case taken up by the Supreme Court concerns whether trustees for a corporate 401(k) are liable years after choosing a class of mutual fund with higher fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you had a choice between two share classes of the same mutual fund — the only difference being that one class charged higher fees and was therefore guaranteed to have poorer returns — the choice would not seem to be difficult.

articles.headline: Bloc in Europe Starts to Balk Over Austerity
articles.snippet: Many of the largest European countries, including France and Italy, are now rebelling against the German gospel of belt-tightening and calling for more radical steps to reverse their slumping fortunes.
articles.abstract: Many of the largest European countries, including France and Italy, are now rebelling against the German gospel of belt-tightening and calling for more radical steps to reverse their slumping fortunes.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILAN — With Europe once again rattling global markets, many of the largest European countries are now rebelling against the German gospel of belt-tightening and demanding more radical steps to reverse their slumping fortunes.
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: In Layers of Gear, Offering Healing Hand to Ebola Patients in Liberia
articles.snippet: Doctors offer Ebola patients simple comforts, like feeding them or cleaning them up. But they also try to restrain their own impulses, because old habits might not be safe.
articles.abstract: Doctors offer Ebola patients simple comforts, like feeding them or cleaning them up. But they also try to restrain their own impulses, because old habits might not be safe.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUAKOKO, Liberia — The first time Dr. Steven Hatch suited up in protective gear at an Ebola treatment center, he was confronted with the weight of his decision to volunteer here. A patient, sweating and heavily soiled, had collapsed in a corridor. “Literally every surface of his body was covered in billions of particles of Ebola,” he recalled.

articles.headline: Regulators Are Gauging Europe’s Banks, and Remedy May Sting a Little
articles.snippet: The results, which are set to be released next weekend, may further rattle the markets if banks unexpectedly have to write down bad loans and quickly raise capital.
articles.abstract: The results, which are set to be released next weekend, may further rattle the markets if banks unexpectedly have to write down bad loans and quickly raise capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The global market turmoil is a vivid reminder that the European crisis didn’t go away — it has just been lying dormant.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Janet Yellen Warns of Inequality Threat
articles.snippet: At a speech in Boston, the Federal Reserve chairwoman said she feared growing disparities in income and wealth were choking Americans’ ability to advance.
articles.abstract: At a speech in Boston, the Federal Reserve chairwoman said she feared growing disparities in income and wealth were choking Americans’ ability to advance.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, used her bully pulpit on Friday to sound the alarm about rising economic inequality.

articles.headline: Amid Tumult, Bonds Prove Steady
articles.snippet: The recent volatility of stocks and the unpredictability of interest rates are a potent reminder to most investors to be diversified.
articles.abstract: The recent volatility of stocks and the unpredictability of interest rates are a potent reminder to most investors to be diversified.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week’s stock market drop and wild gyrations may have been wrenching for investors, but they can’t really be called a surprise. After 27 months with no significant decline and with many valuation measures signaling caution, a chorus of pundits has been predicting a stock market pullback and higher volatility.
